definition.p: On a Windows computer, a batch file is essentially a throw-back to the DOS era. It is a line-oriented set of DOS 6.2 commands (with a few new ones added). When executed, it performs its instructions line-by-line until there is an untrapped error or the instructions are exhausted.
Here are some reasons we use batch files:

ul.li: Though somewhat archaic, every Windows operating system can run a batch file when it is double-clicked.
They tend to be only a few lines long and do simple things like launch a program with a specific set of parameters.
More complex, albeit small, programs would have to be written to do the same things otherwise.
